messages: 69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (00:21): i wonder how the yahoo/bing thing affects searchmonkey
a03bfa2a78d00389c65221c74759cbb4 (00:38): 69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e, I was speaking to a collegue today who had an interesting, though not entirely convincing, proposal for a <pdf> element...
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (00:38): a03bfa2a78d00389c65221c74759cbb4: can you stick a google2569a0eb653e4cf1.html file at the root of the blog.whatwg.org domain?
a03bfa2a78d00389c65221c74759cbb4 (00:38): His use case was for being able to embed PDF documents in web pages, and having native support in the browsers.
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (00:38): i'm trying to register the site in the google webmaster tools console
a03bfa2a78d00389c65221c74759cbb4 (00:39): like what http://www.scribd.com/ is doing, but without flash
a03bfa2a78d00389c65221c74759cbb4 (00:39): 69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e, ok, will do it now
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (00:39): isn't "iframe" enough to do that?
a03bfa2a78d00389c65221c74759cbb4 (00:39): just an empty file with that name?
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (00:39): yeah
a03bfa2a78d00389c65221c74759cbb4 (00:39): that's what I told him
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (00:39): i mean, safari seems to do it fine...
a03bfa2a78d00389c65221c74759cbb4 (00:39): yeah, I know, that was also mentioned. I was just passing along the discussion, in case he decides to present it anyway
a03bfa2a78d00389c65221c74759cbb4 (00:40): http://blog.whatwg.org/google2569a0eb653e4cf1.html

a03bfa2a78d00389c65221c74759cbb4 (00:41): I also questioned him about whether or not an API for controlling the PDF was essential, similar to <video>, but he just seemed to say yes without being able to explain why
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (00:42): heh
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (00:42): thanks a03bfa2a78d00389c65221c74759cbb4
1f8387eb43f131d7c309a90a4e36b5cb (00:44): Man, iframes never occur to me for things like embedding PDFs.
f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220 (00:44): 1f8387eb43f131d7c309a90a4e36b5cb, I think the problem with using iframes now is that most browsers lack native support for PDF
f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220 (00:45): and, IIRC, results in a save as dialog as soon as the page tries to load
1f8387eb43f131d7c309a90a4e36b5cb (00:45): Yeah, but most people have an acceptable plugin already installed (in a crazy world where the adobe plugin is 'acceptable').
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (00:45): ok i resubmitted the blog for the index
f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220 (00:48): 1f8387eb43f131d7c309a90a4e36b5cb, most Mac users wouldn't have the Adobe viewer installed, since Preview.app works just fine for most needs
1f8387eb43f131d7c309a90a4e36b5cb (00:48): how do mac users handle a normal pdf link?
1f8387eb43f131d7c309a90a4e36b5cb (00:48): Does Preview.app intercept those or something?
f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220 (00:48): depends on the browser
f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220 (00:48): Safari just opens it within the browser itself,
f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220 (00:49): Firefox and Opera offer to download the file or open with the default app
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (01:12): gotta love how aria's role=img isn't the same as <img>
65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (01:13): that's funny
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (01:17): also <marquee> is not a role=marquee
caf9142b24098fc664f06d58ba8f7fe2 (01:20): 69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e: i dunno if this is of any interest http://wiki.netsurf-browser.org/Spec/HTML5_Alignment
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (01:21): yeah, that would be good to send to the list
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (01:21): i'm always happy to make the language clearer where it's opaque
caf9142b24098fc664f06d58ba8f7fe2 (01:22): also, it doesn't mention how html aligment does not propagate into TABLE descendants
caf9142b24098fc664f06d58ba8f7fe2 (01:24): also, we have test cases:
caf9142b24098fc664f06d58ba8f7fe2 (01:24): http://source.netsurf-browser.org/trunk/netsurftest/other/aligntests/index.html
caf9142b24098fc664f06d58ba8f7fe2 (01:24): for determining how other browsers handled html alignment & css propertys
caf9142b24098fc664f06d58ba8f7fe2 (01:24): results here: http://source.netsurf-browser.org/trunk/netsurftest/other/aligntests/AlignTestResults.txt
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (01:25): yeah, definitely send that feedback to the list
caf9142b24098fc664f06d58ba8f7fe2 (01:25): ok, which list?
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (01:28): <email/>, or <email/>, or any of the other feedback mechanisms mentioned at the top of the spec
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (01:29): easiest to subscribe to is the first of those
caf9142b24098fc664f06d58ba8f7fe2 (01:29): right, i'll post tomorrow
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (01:29): thanks!
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (01:30): ARIA is confusing
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (01:30): listitem is defined as "A single item in a list, listbox, or directory"
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (01:30): but is not allows as a child of a "listbox"
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (01:30): s/allows/allowed
1f8387eb43f131d7c309a90a4e36b5cb (01:32): 69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e: That looks like a mistake on listitem.  Listbox is only supposed to contain option as children.
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (01:33): does <section> map to role=region?
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (01:33): role=section is abstract...

1f8387eb43f131d7c309a90a4e36b5cb (01:35): Hrm.  The listbox is actually really confusing.  It has both list and select as parents.  List has to have listitem or group children, but selects have option children generally.
1f8387eb43f131d7c309a90a4e36b5cb (01:36): 69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e: role=region seems to be appropriate only if the <section> doesn't map to any of the landmark roles.
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (01:36): what other landmark roles might apply?
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (01:37): main and search?
1f8387eb43f131d7c309a90a4e36b5cb (01:38): application, main, search
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (01:38): contentinfo maybe
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (01:38): not application, surely
1f8387eb43f131d7c309a90a4e36b5cb (01:38): maybe contentinfo if <footer> isn't appropriate
1f8387eb43f131d7c309a90a4e36b5cb (01:38): oh hrm, you're right.  application should be reserved for <article>
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (01:38): i thought it should be reserved for <html>
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (01:39): laughs at how well people manage to agree on this
1f8387eb43f131d7c309a90a4e36b5cb (01:39): A single page can have a document and application section, though.
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (01:39): it can?
65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (01:39): couldn't a page have multiple "applications" if it embeds widgets?
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (01:39): i guess
1f8387eb43f131d7c309a90a4e36b5cb (01:39): that's what I'm getting out of the section, at least.
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (01:39): the definition of "application" is "A region declared as a web application, as opposed to a web document."
65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (01:40): conversely, couldn't an "application" contain a "document", like GMail's content view showing a mail message?
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (01:40): yeah they have that as an example
1f8387eb43f131d7c309a90a4e36b5cb (01:40): possible example of document containing an application: blog with a comment form?
1f8387eb43f131d7c309a90a4e36b5cb (01:40): rich comment form, that is.
65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (01:42): a blog with sidebar widgets
65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (01:42): would be a document containing an application
1f8387eb43f131d7c309a90a4e36b5cb (01:42): 69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e: I would bring up the listitem/listbox thing as a bug.  There's no way to reconcile those two.
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (01:43): the draft i'm looking at doesnt
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (01:43): say where to send comments
1f8387eb43f131d7c309a90a4e36b5cb (01:44): http://www.w3.org/TR/wai-aria/ says to send it to the pfwg list
1f8387eb43f131d7c309a90a4e36b5cb (01:45): it says to copy both
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (01:45): thx
